Jay Team Opens
Grid Season On
Shore Saturday

Cheerleaders Wanted
Among Upper Classes
Upperclassmen are urged to come
out for positions on the cheerleading squad, Reuben Baer, coach
of the cheer-leaders, stated.
"So far, the sophs, juniors, and
seniors have shown a hesitancy to
try out for this activity," he continued. "We hope to mold a wellgroomed bunch which will be a
credit to the University, as tbe
upper classes need not feel reluctant to try their hand at this,"
Baer added.
Ten boys have been practicing
every afternoon in the gymnasium
under Baer's tutelage. From this
group, a team of from five to seven members will be chosen.
"The cheer-leaders will be at all
major athletic contests, but will
previously try to standardize the
cheers," Baer asserted.

Piccolo Player Won't
Don R.O.T.0. Uniform
WANTED—A militaristic piccolo player. Apply to Ed Ottenheimer, Hopkins Band leader before next Monday at 5 P. M., when
the Band, resplendent in R. 0. T.
C. uniforms, supplies the music,
for drill. Must be willing to play
in uniform, without fear of becoming a Blackshirt (from the heat)!
The reason for this ad is obvious: the Band has but one piccolo player, name withheld, and
he is a member of the local branch
of the N. S. L.; hence, to supply
music for the local "army", would
be bad enough to do so in their
uniform would be worse.
The result is that on Mondays
the Band will play only the deeper
notes to Mars unless a patrioticminded successor appears.

Dr. Bowman Intimates That
"Shelter Belt" May Be Influencing Elections Factor

Tapped By Frat
President Illustrates Speech
With Slides Of Farms,
Maps Of Dry Regions
After being presented with a laurel
wreath indicative of his induction into 0. D. K., President Isaiah Bowman
spoke to the assembly on the drought
area of the west, later pointing out
its possible national importance.
With the aid of lantern slides, Dr.
Bowman showed how erosion and
lack of cultivation was ruining the
farm lands in the west. He also told
how poor farming conditions were
further aggravated by natural causes.
Delving into his trip into the western farming lands, Dr. Bowman told
of the agricultural aspects he found
in this area. In this manner he supplemented the slides, many of which
were photographs of the arid wastes
of the west.

Deaf, Dumb and Blind

Fashions In Love

By HAROLD M. KROPMAN
Lord, how are they increased that trouble me:
Many are they that rise up against me . . . Psalm
III, line 2 . . .
Particularly apropo is the above quotation just about
this time. Seniors are being shown the dark and dismal side of life by having the senior essay list rubbed
over their faces, made into handkerchiefs and towels,
and ground up and placed in their food—just so they
won't forget about it. Juniors are learning to spend
twenty-four and forty-eight hours at a time parted from
their light o' loves. Sophomores and freshmen do battle
every day with their arch-enemies, the profs. Quizzs,
papers and readings are thrust on everyone . . . Is
there no peace?

(From Reader's Digest)

even in love making. The vogue fifty years ago was for a man to approach a lady in a very delicate manner and about halfway, he had to stop
short. The woman was far too precious, too angelic, to touch. This

HOUGH large,the Bell System is simple in structure.

T

Think of it as a tree.
Branches: 24 associated operating companies, each
attuned to the area it serves.
Trunk: The American Telephone and Telegraph
Company, which coordinates all system activities.
Roots: Bell Telephone Laboratories and Western
Electric, whose functions are scientific research and
manufacture; Long Lines Department of A. T. and T.,
which through its country-wide network of wires links
together the 24 operating companies, handles overseas
service; Advisory Staff of A. T. and T., which advises
the operating companies on all phases of telephone
operation and searches constantly for better methods.

Jay Team Opens
Grid Season On
Shore Saturday

Cheerleaders Wanted
Among Upper Classes
Upperclassmen are urged to come
out for positions on the cheerleading squad, Reuben Baer, coach
of the cheer-leaders, stated.
"So far, the sophs, juniors, and
seniors have shown a hesitancy to
try out for this activity," he continued. "We hope to mold a wellgroomed bunch which will be a
credit to the University, as tbe
upper classes need not feel reluctant to try their hand at this,"
Baer added.
Ten boys have been practicing
every afternoon in the gymnasium
under Baer's tutelage. From this
group, a team of from five to seven members will be chosen.
"The cheer-leaders will be at all
major athletic contests, but will
previously try to standardize the
cheers," Baer asserted.

Fast Backfield; Tough
Well-Drilled Men In Line

officially inaugurate the 1935 season

Piccolo Player Won't
Don R.O.T.0. Uniform
WANTED—A militaristic piccolo player. Apply to Ed Ottenheimer, Hopkins Band leader before next Monday at 5 P. M., when
the Band, resplendent in R. 0. T.
C. uniforms, supplies the music,
for drill. Must be willing to play
in uniform, without fear of becoming a Blackshirt (from the heat)!
The reason for this ad is obvious: the Band has but one piccolo player, name withheld, and
he is a member of the local branch
of the N. S. L.; hence, to supply
music for the local "army", would
be bad enough to do so in their
uniform would be worse.
The result is that on Mondays
the Band will play only the deeper
notes to Mars unless a patrioticminded successor appears.

farm lands in the west. He also told
how poor farming conditions were
further aggravated by natural causes.
Delving into his trip into the western farming lands, Dr. Bowman told
of the agricultural aspects he found
in this area. In this manner he supplemented the slides, many of which
were photographs of the arid wastes
of the west.

Fashions In Love

By HAROLD M. KROPMAN
Lord, how are they increased that trouble me:
Many are they that rise up against me . . . Psalm
III, line 2 . . .
Particularly apropo is the above quotation just about
this time. Seniors are being shown the dark and dismal side of life by having the senior essay list rubbed
over their faces, made into handkerchiefs and towels,
and ground up and placed in their food—just so they
won't forget about it. Juniors are learning to spend
twenty-four and forty-eight hours at a time parted from
their light o' loves. Sophomores and freshmen do battle
every day with their arch-enemies, the profs. Quizzs,
papers and readings are thrust on everyone . . . Is
there no peace?

(From Reader's Digest)

HOUGH large,the Bell System is simple in structure.

Think of it as a tree.
Branches: 24 associated operating companies, each
attuned to the area it serves.
Trunk: The American Telephone and Telegraph
Company, which coordinates all system activities.
Roots: Bell Telephone Laboratories and Western
Electric, whose functions are scientific research and
manufacture; Long Lines Department of A. T. and T.,
which through its country-wide network of wires links
together the 24 operating companies, handles overseas
service; Advisory Staff of A. T. and T., which advises
the operating companies on all phases of telephone
operation and searches constantly for better methods.
